title: Honeybees go 'whoop!' when they bump into each other | Metro News
text:
Ashitha Nagesh for Metro.co.uk Tuesday 14 Feb 2017 5:04 pm Aw (Picture: Getty Images) 
You didn’t think it was possible, but prepare to love bees even more than you already do. 
Apparently when honeybees bump into each other, they let out a little surprised ‘whoop!’ Man with germ phobia loses licence because he won't blow into breathalyser 
Adorable, right? 
Scientists used to think this ‘whooping’– a short vibrational pulse – was either a way to ask for food, or a signal to each other to stop what they were doing. 
But according to New Scientist , researchers at Nottingham Trent University found that the whooping is much more common than previously thought. 
Accelerometers recorded a hive of bees for a year, and ended up picking up around six or seven whoops a minute in just one small area of the honeycomb. 
Listen to the bees whooping on New Scientist’s Soundcloud: 
‘There’s no way a bee was trying to inhibit another one that frequently, and there’s no way a bee would request food that frequently,’ lead researcher Martin Bencsik told NS. Dog owners are more sexually attractive than people who own cats 
He also found that it was easy to make the bees whoop – you just had to knock gently on the hive’s wooden wall. 
To find out more, the scientists placed cameras inside the hive – which is when they discovered that the bees made the noise when they bumped into each other. 
‘We suggest that, in the majority of cases, it is bees being startled that produces the signal,’ Bencsik added. More
